facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 19, 1957, of the Bombay High Court at Rajkot in Criminal Appeal No. 137 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 19, 1957, of the Bombay High Court at Rajkot in Criminal Appeal No. 137 of 1957, arising out of the Judgment and order dated August 31, 1957, of the Sessions Judge, Sorath Division, Junagadh, in Sessions Case No. 26 of 1957.

facts.text: Arising out of the Judgment and order dated August 31, 1957, of the Sessions Judge, Sorath Division, Junagadh, in Sessions Case No. 26 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the Judgment and order dated August 31, 1957, of the Sessions Judge, Sorath Division, Junagadh, in Sessions Case No. 26 of 1957. K. Chatterjee, for the appellant. J. Umrigar and B. H. Dhebar, for the respondent. 1960, February, 26.

facts.text: Appellant convicted under s. 304, Part I of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to imprisonment for life

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM, J.-This appeal is by special leave. The appellant was companyvicted under s. 304, Part I of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to, imprisonment for life. He appealed to the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: High Court reduced the sentence from imprisonment for life to 10 years rigorous imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: According to the judgment of the High Court the appeal was admitted only on the point of sentence. The High Court reduced the sentence from imprisonment for life to 10 years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Appellant caused the death of Zina Hira on April 6, 1957

anchor.surface_text: Shortly stated, the case of the prosecution was that the appellant had caused the death of Zina Hira on April 6, 1957, when the deceased was returning from an adjoining village to the village of his residence.

facts.text: Deceased was returning from an adjoining village to the village of his residence

anchor.surface_text: when the deceased was returning from an adjoining village to the village of his residence. The appellant met him on the way and accused him of having companymitted theft in the appellants house which the deceased denied.

facts.text: Appellant accused deceased of having committed theft in the appellants house which the deceased denied

anchor.surface_text: The appellant met him on the way and accused him of having companymitted theft in the appellants house which the deceased denied. Upon this the appellant attacked him with a stick which had iron rings round it.

facts.text: Appellant attacked deceased with a stick which had iron rings round it

anchor.surface_text: Upon this the appellant attacked him with a stick which had iron rings round it. A number of blows were given by the appellant with this stick in companysequence of which Zina Hira fell down.

facts.text: A number of blows were given by the appellant with this stick in sequence of which Zina Hira fell down

anchor.surface_text: A number of blows were given by the appellant with this stick in companysequence of which Zina Hira fell down. Although a doctor was called for from Keshod, 8 miles away, ultimately the deceased was taken to Junagadh for better medical treatment but died on the way in the early hours of the morning of April 7.

facts.text: Deceased died on the way to Junagadh in the early hours of the morning of April 7

anchor.surface_text: Although a doctor was called for from Keshod, 8 miles away, ultimately the deceased was taken to Junagadh for better medical treatment but died on the way in the early hours of the morning of April 7.

facts.text: Appellant was not present at the scene of the crime and pleaded not guilty

anchor.surface_text: According to the case of the appellant he was number present at the scene of the crime and pleaded number guilty to the charge.

facts.text: There was an eye-witness Bava Tapu who saw the appellant assaulting the deceased with a stick

anchor.surface_text: It is clear to us from a perusal of the evidence that the case has been amply proved against the appellant. There was an eye-witness who saw the appellant assaulting the deceased with a stick.

facts.text: Bava Tapu was in some way related to the deceased, which he attempted to deny

anchor.surface_text: He was in some way related to the deceased, which he attempted to deny, otherwise there is numberhing in his evidence to induce a companyrt to distrust his testimony.

facts.text: Bava Tapu immediately after the assault went to the Police Patel of Simroli, one Keshav, and told him that the deceased had been assaulted by the appellant

anchor.surface_text: This eye-witness, Bava Tapu, immediately after the assault, went to the Police Patel of Simroli, one Keshav, and told him that the deceased had been assaulted by the appellant. Keshav companyroborated Bava Tapu in this respect.

facts.text: Keshav corroborated Bava Tapu

anchor.surface_text: Keshav companyroborated Bava Tapu in this respect. Keshavs evidence in this respect is also companyroborated by Natha Jiwa who stated that Bava Tapu came and informed Keshav that Zina Hira had been severely assaulted and injured by the appellant.

facts.text: Natha Jiwa and Bogha Jiwa corroborated Keshav

anchor.surface_text: Keshavs evidence in this respect is also companyroborated by Natha Jiwa who stated that Bava Tapu came and informed Keshav that Zina Hira had been severely assaulted and injured by the appellant. Bogha Jiwa also companyroborated Keshav in this respect.

facts.text: There was the dying declaration of the deceased as to who his assailant was

anchor.surface_text: None of these witnesses have any real motive to depose against the appellant. In addition to this evidence there was the dying declaration of the deceased as to who his assailant was.

facts.text: Recovery of a stick buried underground at the instance of the appellant which was found to be stained with human blood according to the report of the Serologist

anchor.surface_text: Furthermore, there was the recovery of a stick buried underground at the instance of the appellant which was found to be stained with human blood according to the report of the Serologist. The other circumstantial evidence need number be referred to.

facts.text: No reference to accusation of theft in the First Information lodged by Keshav

anchor.surface_text: It was urged on behalf of the appellant that the reason for the appellant assaulting the deceased companyld number be true as numberreference was made to it in the First Information lodged by Keshav.

facts.text: No information of the theft had been lodged by the appellant at the thana

anchor.surface_text: Reference also was made to the evidence of the Police Officer Priyakant that numberinformation of the theft had been lodged by the appellant at the thana.

facts.text: Appellant in his statement denied that the deceased had committed any theft in his house

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in his statement denied that the deceased had companymitted any theft in his house and the witness Karsan brother of the appellant had stated in cross examination that there had been numbertheft in their house.

facts.text: Karsan brother of the appellant stated there had been no theft in their house

anchor.surface_text: and the witness Karsan brother of the appellant had stated in cross examination that there had been numbertheft in their house. This witness was examined by the prosecution but was declared hostile and permission was granted by the Court to cross-examine him.

facts.text: The evidence established beyond doubt that the appellant had struck the deceased several blows with a stick and thus caused his death

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, therefore, that the evidence in the case which we have carefully examined and see numbergood reason to distrust, established beyond doubt that the appellant had struck the deceased several blows with a stick and thus caused his death.

facts.text: Appellant guilty at least under s. 304 of the Indian Penal Code as found by the trial court

anchor.surface_text: He was, therefore, guilty at least under s. 304 of the Indian Penal Code as found by the trial companyrt.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 19, 1957, of the Bombay High Court at Rajkot in Criminal Appeal No. 137 of 1957, arising out of the Judgment and order dated August 31, 1957, of the Sessions Judge, Sorath Division, Junagadh, in Sessions Case No. 26 of 1957.

The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM, J.-This appeal is by special leave. The appellant was convicted under s. 304, Part I of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to, imprisonment for life. He appealed to the Bombay High Court.

holdings.text: An Appellate Court has no power to direct that an appeal shall be heard only on the point of sentence; such an order is neither summary dismissal under s.421 nor compliance with s.422

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us, however, having regard to the provisions of the Code, that while an Appellate Court has power to dismiss an appeal summarily, if it considers that there is no sufficient ground for interfering, it has numberpower to direct, as in the case before us, that the appeal shall be heard only on the point of sentence. Such an order is number an order of

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions of ss.421-422 require either full summary dismissal or notice for complete hearing on conviction and sentence; precludes partial admission; in line with Privy Council in Dahu Raut

holdings.text: Power under s.423 to reduce sentence exercisable only after requirements of s.422 complied with; does not permit admitting appeal only on sentence

anchor.surface_text: under s. 423 an Appellate Court had the power to reduce the sentence. That is so, but that power can only be exercised after the requirements of s. 422 have been complied with The Appellate Court after hearing the appeal, certainly has the power in finally disposing of the appeal to reduce the sentence but that does number entitle it to direct that an appeal is admitted only on the question of sentence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme mandates procedural compliance with notice under s.422 before invoking appellate powers under s.423

holdings.text: The form of the order admitting the appeal only on the point of sentence in the present case was invalid

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the form of the order admitting the appeal in the present case was invalid and the appellant could have insisted that since the appeal had number been summarily dismissed, the High Court should have heard his appeal on the merits as well.

In these circumstances reference need number be made to the view expressed by the Patna High Court in 1932 I.L.R. II Pat. 697 which was a judgment before the decision of the Privy Council in Dahu Rauts case. The decision of the Bombay High Court in I.L.R. 1937 Bom. 365 endeavoured to find a way in which the difficulty companyld be resolved where the Appellate Court was of the opinion that only the question of sentence was involved. For the purposes of this appeal it is unnecessary for us to say anything about this decision because what was stated there does number arise for companysideration, as, in the present case, according to the judgment of the High Court, the appeal was admitted only on the point of sentence.

precedents.cited_proposition: View on admitting appeal only on sentence

anchor.surface_text: I.L.R. 1937 Bom. 365 endeavoured to find a way in which the difficulty companyld be resolved where the Appellate Court was of the opinion that only the question of sentence was involved. For the purposes of this appeal it is unnecessary for us to say anything about this decision because what was stated there does number arise for companysideration, as, in the present case, according to the judgment of the High Court, the appeal was admitted only on the point of sentence. It was also urged by Mr. Umrigar that under s. 423 an Appellate Court had the power to reduce the sentence. That is so, but that power can only be exercised after the requirements of s. 422 have been companyplied with The Appellate Court after hearing the appeal, certainly has the power in finally disposing of the appeal to reduce the sentence but that does number entitle it to direct that an appeal is admitted only on the question of sentence.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, therefore, that the evidence in the case which we have carefully examined and see numbergood reason to distrust, established beyond doubt that the appellant had struck the deceased several blows with a stick and thus caused his death. He was, therefore, guilty at least under s. 304 of the Indian Penal Code as found by the trial companyrt.

It is clear, therefore, that the evidence in the case which we have carefully examined and see numbergood reason to distrust, established beyond doubt that the appellant had struck the deceased several blows with a stick and thus caused his death. He was, therefore, guilty at least under s. 304 of the Indian Penal Code as found by the trial companyrt.
